title: Coming soon: the palace letters
description: Ever since the dramatic dismissal of Gough Whitlam’s Labor government in November 1975, there has been speculation about the Queen’s role in the episode. On the morning of Tuesday 14 July, 200 exchanges between the Queen, her private secretary and Australia’s then governor general will be released. We’re putting Full Story out later today so we can tell you what’s inside the letters and what it means for Australia.
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and produced by Miles Martignoni

title: The scandal of millions of Americans deprived of running water
description: Guardian US environmental justice reporter Nina Lakhani reports on her landmark investigation into America’s water crisis, revealing that millions of Americans are facing unaffordable bills for running water and risk being disconnected or losing their homes
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Nina Lakhani. Produced by Rose de Larrabeiti, Courtney Yusuf and AAxel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates and Miles Martignoni

title: Power, privilege and sexual harassment in the Australian legal profession
description: Last month, an independent investigation commissioned by the high court of Australia found former high court justice Dyson Heydon sexually harassed six junior court staff, allegations which Heydon categorically denies. But this case has prompted an outpouring of stories about a culture of harassment and gender bias in the legal industry
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Naaman Zhou and Catharine Lumby. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Gabrielle Jackson and Miles Martignoni

title: Maria Ressa and the increasing attacks on the free press in the Philippines
description: One of the most prominent journalists in the Philippines has been convicted of ‘cyberlibel’ in a court process condemned by human rights groups. Journalist Carmela Fonbuena in Manila describes the chilling effect the verdict has had on free expression
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Carmela Fonbuena. Produced by Elizabeth Cassin and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates and Joe Koning

title: How Melbourne ended up under a second Covid-19 lockdown
description: For weeks now the Victorian government has been desperately trying to get the coronavirus outbreak under control. It locked down postcodes, public housing towers and finally Melbourne itself. In this episode of Full Story, reporter Melissa Davey explains how it all unfolded
contributors: Hosted by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Melissa Davey. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Inside the Covid-19 hard lockdown of Melbourne's public housing towers
description: On Saturday afternoon, 3,000 people living in nine public housing towers in the suburbs of Flemington of North Melbourne found themselves placed under a ‘hard lockdown’ to help stem the spread of Covid-19, thanks to a sudden announcement from the Victorian government. They cannot leave their units, except for emergencies, are subject to mandatory testing and are being monitored by 500 police officers. We spoke to Hiba Shanino, one of those confined in the towers
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Understanding white privilege, with Reni Eddo-Lodge
description: Reni Eddo-Lodge, author of the 2017 book Why I’m No Longer Talking to White People About Race talks to the Observer’s Nosheen Iqbal about global discussions on racism following the death of George Floyd
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys with Nosheen Iqbal and Reni Eddo-Lodge; produced by Hannah Moore and Axel Kacoutié; executive producers Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Adapted by Gabrielle Jackson and Joe Koning

title: What's the big deal about the Eden-Monaro byelection?
description: Ravaged by the twin crises of the bushfires and pandemic, the seat of Eden-Monaro in the south-east of NSW goes to a byelection on Saturday. If the Coalition wins, it will be the first time in a century the government has won a seat from the opposition in a byelection and that will be bad news for Labor leader Anthony Albanese. Paul Karp takes a look at the contest and explains what the outcomes could mean
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Paul Karp. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: The green recovery: what is it and will Australia miss a once in a lifetime opportunity?
description: As countries around the world begin restarting their economies after the coronavirus crisis, a growing chorus of prominent leaders have labelled this is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to tackle climate change by targeting post-pandemic stimulus toward areas that promote renewable energy. Will Australia take heed or continue to rely on fossil fuels?
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Adam Morton. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: How did Jordan end up with the highest smoking rate in the world?
description: When international correspondent Michael Safi began looking into why Jordan had become the country with the world’s highest smoking rates, he began to uncover what public health advocates have described as widespread interference in policymaking by multinational tobacco companies
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Michael Safi. Produced by Joshua Kelly and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates and Miles Martignoni

title: Covid-19 and the long history of ignoring women in medical research
description: Around the world men and women are responding differently to Covid-19 yet few countries are taking note of these differences. This isn’t unique to this pandemic but typical of how female biology has been largely ignored when it comes to medical research. Gabrielle Jackson examines the resulting knowledge gap and the repercussions for how women and gender diverse people are treated in our medical system
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Gabrielle Jackson. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: How damaging is John Bolton's scathing account of Donald Trump's presidency?
description: The publication of former US national security adviser John Bolton’s White House memoir has caused a sensation. Jonathan Freedland assesses the lurid claims of cosying up to authoritarian leaders as well as descriptions of the ‘stunning’ ignorance of Donald Trump
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Jonathan Freedland. Produced by Courtney Yusuf and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates and Joe Koning

title: What can we learn about better policing from Newark?
description: The New Jersey city had one of the worst reputations for police violence in the US, but as the Guardian’s Ankita Rao discovers, it is leading the charge for reform under a new mayor
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Ankita Rao. Produced by Serena Barker-Singh and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates and Miles Martignoni

title: What caused Victoria's Covid-19 spike and can it be contained?
description: Over the past week, the Australian state of Victoria has seen a surge in coronavirus cases, with a dozen or so new Covid-19 cases each day popping up in hotspots around Melbourne. Melissa Davey explains what’s causing this spike, and the attempts to contain the spread of the virus, before it turns into a second wave
contributors: Reported by Melissa Davey and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and  Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson.

title: The destruction of a 46,000-year-old cave and the backlash for Australia’s mining industry
description: In Western Australia, on the lands of the Puutu Kunti Kurrama and Pinikura people, there was a 46,000-year-old cave, where thousands of artefacts were discovered, revealing incredible things about the history of this continent. In late May Rio Tinto – one of the world’s biggest mining companies – blew it up. Calla Wahlquist explores the archaic law that allowed this to happen, and the ensuing backlash that could change how the mining industry operates  Culture warriors obsessed with statues ignore Rio Tinto’s vandalism of Indigenous heritage
contributors: Reported by Calla Wahlquist and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson.

title: Why was Donald Trump's 'comeback' rally in Tulsa, the site of a massacre?
description: The US president’s decision to hold his first rally since the coronavirus lockdown in Tulsa, Oklahoma, has ignited fresh controversy. The city was home to one of America’s worst ever acts of racial violence in 1921, a moment marked in recent Black Lives Matter protests, and Oklahoma is now seeing a new wave of coronavirus infections. So why did Trump chose Tulsa?
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Oliver Laughland. Produced by Mythili Rao and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson abd Phil Maynard. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates and Miles Martignoni

title: Investigating a case of historical child sexual abuse in NSW schools
description: Throughout his three decades working in the public school system, Cletus O’Connor allegedly abused at least 14 boys, all of them Indigenous. Michael McGowan explains the methods O’Connor used to gain the trust of young boys and examines why it has taken so long for the NSW government to publicly acknowledge the abuse
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Michael McGowan. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Patrick Keneally

title: Facebook v Twitter: how to handle Donald Trump
description: As protests erupted throughout the US, Donald Trump posted incendiary comments to social media. While Twitter hid the president’s post, Facebook took no action. The Guardian’s technology editor, Alex Hern, looks at what happened next
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Alex Hern. Produced by Hannah Moore and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson

title: The questionable use of taxpayer-funded travel expenses by politicians
description: Since Brownyn Bishop’s infamous helicopter ride, have politicians stopped charging the taxpayer for things they shouldn’t be? Transparency reporter Christopher Knaus investigates the latest expense reports, including one involving the deputy prime minister, an RAAF chartered plane and the Melbourne cup.
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Christopher Knaus. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning.  The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: After 13 years has the disappearance of Madeleine McCann been solved?
description: The disappearance of a three -year-old British girl at a Portuguese holiday resort in 2007 quickly became a global news story as the hunt for her grew ever more extensive. Thirteen years later, with the mystery still unsolved, German police revealed they had a new prime suspect. Is there now a conclusion in sight?
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys , reported by Esther Addley and Sandra Laville. Produced by Joshua Kelly, Courtney Yusuf and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates
